Shane Duan wrote:
> 
> Paul Michali wrote:
>
> > What I do in JBuilder4, is create two projects, one that has the source
> > for the
> > app and one that has the source for the test files and refers to the
> > sources in
> > the first project.
> >
> > In the test project, I select the menu Project -> Project Properties...
> > and
> > under the "Required Libraries" tab I pick the "Add..." button and
> > navigate
> > to the JUnit project and select the junit.jar file. Now, I've done this
> > a
> > bunch of times and JUnit is there to select as a library. The first time
> > you
> > do this, you may have to pick "Add..." and then click on the "New...",
> > fill
> > out the form and click on the "Add" button to select the junit.jar file
> > for
> > the library path.
> >
> 
> I don't think you have to create a project for JUnit just so that you can add it as a library.  That'll be kind of weird.

Sorry, I guess I wasn't clear about what I do. Let me try to clarify...

When I have an application that I'm going to be testing, I create two
projects
that are in parallel directories. One holds the original program and the
other
directory holds the test classes that I develop to test the program.
That
second project makes use of JUnit and will have classes that are
subclasses of
TestCase and therefore will depend on the JUnit library. I usually use
the
same package for both projects (the app and the test app).

As a result, in the test project, I specify JUnit as a required library
so
that it will build. That was what I was trying to explain in my post.

I use two parallel directories and that ends up with duplicates of the
class
files (the test project will build the test sources and the program
sources).
I guess you could put the test files in the same tree as the program
files,
however, with JBuilder, I haven't figured out how to get it to place the
test
class files in a different place (to separate test classes from app
classes).

I'd be interested in hearing about other ways to do this...


> 
> And also you can specify the source code jar file, which is bundled in the download, for JUnit in the library, then you can browse the source
> code of JUnit classes without extracting the files.  Personally I like this feature a lot.

Cool! I hadn't tried that. I would run JAR and extract the sources to a
directory
and then browse the files. This sounds much easier.
